description: Strengthen your understanding of respectful behaviour in the workplace and why it matters. Understand how you can contribute to a respectful workplace and your responsibilities under policy and legislation and the resources available to support you if you experience or witness a respectful workplace issue.

hero.heading: Respectful Workplace
hero.text:
All BC Public Service employees have the right to be respected, and to work in an environment free from racism or any other form of discrimination. 
As stated in Where Ideas Work, the 2023 Corporate Plan, “the responsibility for building and maintaining a respectful workplace is shared by everyone in the BC Public Service.”

name: Respectful Workplace

bookmarks.context: Discover what a respectful workplace means, along with the rights and expectations of BC Public Service employees, to recognize its importance.
bookmarks.description:
A respectful workplace is one where integrity is at the forefront and all employees are treated fairly. 
Learning about a respectful workplace is important as all BC Public Service employees play a role in building and maintaining respect in the workplace which also helps us maintain the trust and confidence of British Columbians.
It is also important that we understand what is required of us under BC Public Service policies and relevant legislation, including expected workplace behaviour.
bookmarks.title: Defining a respectful workplace and outlining why it is important.

bookmarks.context: Review the BC Public Service Corporate values to see how they align to a respectful workplace especially accountability and the overarching value of integrity.
bookmarks.description: A summary of the BC Public Service corporate values.
bookmarks.title: BC Public Service corporate values

bookmarks.context: Review the corporate plan which outlines concrete actions to renew the public service which in turn supports a respectful workplace.
bookmarks.description: The corporate HR plan sets the strategic vision and guiding direction for the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: Corporate HR Plan for the BC Public Service

bookmarks.context:
Under the Standards of Conduct, employees actions must contribute to a positive work environment and employees must not engage in bullying, discrimination or any other inappropriate conduct compromising the integrity of the BC Public Service. 
Review the Standards of Conduct (HR Policy 09) to learn more about your responsibilities as an employee.
bookmarks.description: The Standards of Conduct are a condition of employment and govern employee conduct in areas such as workplace behaviour, allegations of wrongdoing, conflicts of interest, etc.
bookmarks.title: Standards of Conduct for BC Public Service employees

steps.name: Step 1: What is a respectful workplace and why is it important?
steps.why: This first step will create an understanding of what a respectful workplace in the BC Public Service is and why it is important.

bookmarks.context: The Human Rights Code prohibits discrimination in the workplace. Learn about the purposes of this Code and how it supports a respectful workplace.
bookmarks.description: The Human Rights Code helps make sure everyone can participate equally in daily life in British Columbia. The Code protects you from harmful treatment, such as, discrimination.
bookmarks.title: British Columbia's Human Rights Code

bookmarks.context: In a respectful workplace, discriminatory, bullying, or harassing behaviors are not acceptable. Review this page for more information on a range of inappropriate behaviors that constitute discrimination, bullying, and harassment. It includes examples and clarifies the misuse of supervisory authority.
bookmarks.description: This page provides definitions of discrimination, bullying, harassment and explains what behaviours are considered bullying and harassment and what behaviours are not.
bookmarks.title: Define discrimination, bullying and harassment

bookmarks.context: Read the policies which outline the duty to take reasonable care to protect the health and safety of themselves and other persons, including taking reasonable steps to prevent or minimize workplace bullying and harassment.
bookmarks.description: WorkSafeBC Occupational Health and Safety Policies under the Workers Compensation Act outline responsibilities for both employees and supervisors to prevent and address bullying and harassment in the workplace.
bookmarks.title: WorkSafeBC Occupational Health and Safety Policies

bookmarks.description: This checklist identifies actions BC Public Service employees can take to ensure the BC Public Service remains a respectful work environment free from discrimination, bullying and harassment.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful Workplace: Checklist for Employees

bookmarks.description: This checklist identifies actions supervisors in the BC Public Service can take to contribute to a respectful workplace free from discrimination, bullying and harassment.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful Workplace: Checklist for Supervisors

bookmarks.context: This policy aims to create safe and healthy workplaces in the BC Public Service, where discrimination, bullying, and harassment are not tolerated.  Review the policy to understand what it covers and your responsibilities.
bookmarks.description: This HR policy provides a standard set of principles, processes, definitions and rules for maintaining a respectful workplace within the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace

steps.name: Step 2: Legislation and policies that support a respectful workplace.
steps.why: Identify corporate policies and legislation related to respectful workplaces, the types of behaviours to avoid, and actions that contribute to a respectful workplace culture.

bookmarks.context: Review page five of the Human Resources Policy 11 where the process to follow if you experience or witness firsthand inappropriate or disrespectful workplace behaviour is identified.
bookmarks.description: This HR policy provides a standard set of principles, processes, definitions and rules for maintaining a respectful workplace within the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace

bookmarks.context:
The Conflict Management Office (CMO) can help resolve interpersonal and team-related workplace conflict that stems from inappropriate or disrespectful workplace behaviour. The CMO offers a range of services including conflict coaching, meditation, facilitation and a workplace improvement process. 
Note some services are restricted to supervisors.
bookmarks.description: The Conflict Management Office helps to effectively resolve interpersonal and team related workplace conflict. They empower and support you to engage in challenging conversations that respect differences, with the aim to lead to meaningful and lasting resolution.
bookmarks.title: Conflict Management Office

bookmarks.context:
The formal complaint process will depend on whether you are a bargaining unit or excluded employee. This page provides information and links to information for BCGEU and PEA collective agreements and the procedures for excluded staff.
    Review HR Policy 11:
  • Appendix 1 - Complaint Procedures: Bargaining Unit Employees
  • Appendix 2 - Complaint Procedures: Excluded Employees/Appointees
bookmarks.description: This page explains how to launch a formal complaint if informal methods of resolving a respectful workplace issue are not successful or not appropriate.
bookmarks.title: Launch a formal complaint

bookmarks.context: Review resources provided through the Employee and Family Assistance Services (EFAS) provider, TELUS Health (formerly LifeWorks). Including critical incident response services and supervisor resources.
bookmarks.description: Counselling support is a free service available to public service employees and can assist in dealing with difficult work situations or conflicts. A Trauma Assist clinical support program is also offered when needed.
bookmarks.title: Counselling support

steps.name: Step 3: What resources are available should I experience or witness inappropriate or disrespectful behaviour?
steps.why: Discover resources to support you if you experience or witness inappropriate or disrespectful behaviour.

bookmarks.description: This virtually delivered course for leaders at all levels introduces foundational skills and practices for successful coaching conversations toward achieving desired results.
bookmarks.title: Coaching 101: Coaching Approach to Conversations Essentials

bookmarks.description: Register for Addressing Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace. This 30-min online training focuses on workplace policies and regulations, as set in the Standards of Conduct, Collective Agreement and WorkSafe BC, and how these apply to employees and supervisors.
bookmarks.title: Addressing Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace e-learning

bookmarks.description: Explore tools and strategies to increase self-awareness and the important role it plays in promoting a respectful and inclusive workplace culture.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful and Inclusive Workplace 101: Self-Awareness

bookmarks.description: Explore behaviours, attitudes, policies, guidelines, and tools that maintain and enhance trust in the workplace.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful and Inclusive Workplace 102: Promoting Trust

bookmarks.description: Explore the role inclusive communication practices play in building respectful and inclusive workplaces.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful and Inclusive Workplace 103: Inclusive Communication

bookmarks.description: Explore behaviours and actions that promote a respectful and inclusive workplace culture and strategies to become active contributors to the culture we want.
bookmarks.title: Building a Respectful and Inclusive Workplace 104: Creating our Culture

bookmarks.description: This webinar explores the strategies and approaches to deepening the connection between conversations and achieving desirable personal and workplace outcomes.
bookmarks.title: Fierce Foundations

bookmarks.description: Inclusion in the workplace can be improved by considering bias, perspective-taking, social location and frame of reference. Explore these concepts and engage in this 90-minute thought-provoking workshop offered by the Learning Centre.
bookmarks.title: The Impact of Bias and Assumption on Workplace Inclusion

bookmarks.description: What guides equity, diversity and inclusion in the BC Public Service? Launch this Learning Centre course to learn more.
bookmarks.title: Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Essentials

bookmarks.description: This short webinar will introduce you to psychological health and safety in the workplace. You will learn about the psycho-social factors of psychological safety, what they look like in our daily work environment, their influence and their impact.
bookmarks.title: Orientation to Psychological Health and Safety in the Workplace

bookmarks.description: People Leaders play a key role in building a respectful workplace and need to keep their own skills fresh.
bookmarks.title: Learning for People Leaders

steps.name: Step 4: Respectful workplace learning opportunities.
steps.why: Explore additional learning opportunities to deepen your knowledge of respectful workplaces.

summary:
All BC Public Service employees have the right to be respected, and to work in an environment free from racism or any other form of discrimination. 
As stated in Where Ideas Work, the 2023 Corporate Plan, “the responsibility for building and maintaining a respectful workplace is shared by everyone in the BC Public Service.”

summaryModules.name: Step 1: What is a respectful workplace and why is it important?
Step 2: Legislation and policies that support a respectful workplace.
Step 3: What resources are available should I experience or witness inappropriate or disrespectful behaviour?

title: Respectful Workplace

acknowledgments:
The Corporate Learning Branch would like to acknowledge the support we received from many of our colleagues and partners in multiple branches/ministries during the development of this learning resource. We also appreciate the invaluable comments we received during our engagement sessions.

In particular, our sincere thanks go out to colleagues and partners at the following entities:

* Policy & Legislation, BC Data Service, CITZ
* Multiculturalism & Anti-Racism Branch, AG
* PSA REDI, Policy and Employee Relations
* SDPR Inclusion, Diversity and Cultural Safety (IDCS) & Anti-Racism 101 course
* BIPOC Employee Resource Group
* Indigenous Employees Network
contentWarning:
> "Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced." — James Baldwin

This learning pathway deals with sensitive topics. It touches on racism, inequity, power structures and the inherent imbalances that exist in our society, culture, and organizations.

The content of this pathway is primarily tailored for those new to the subject area. We, however, recognize that thousands of BC Public Service employees who represent the Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) and other marginalized communities are also completing this learning and may have a different baseline of knowledge and lived experience.

Irrespective of your life experiences, be prepared for moments when you will feel uncomfortable. Know that discomfort is normal and is often a prerequisite for positive change and growth. When you feel discomfort, it's not a sign that something is wrong — it's a sign that you are doing something right.

Some learners may find the training overwhelming due to personal experiences with racism and other forms of discrimination. In such circumstances, we encourage you to step back, prioritize emotional health, and return to the content.

As employees, you have access to [Employee and Family Assistance Services](https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/careers-myhr/all-employees/health-safety-and-sick-leave-resources/health/efas?keyword=EFAS) anytime you need. You will also find resources and other workplace support mechanisms related to anti-racism within module four and five of these pathways.

Canadians in crisis can also call or text 9-8-8 24/7 to access bilingual, trauma-informed, and culturally appropriate mental health, and suicide prevention support.

Let's dive into the learning journey with open minds and hearts as we strive to make BC Public Service an equitable, inclusive, and anti-racist organization.

In the words of Maya Angelou, **"Do the best you can until you know better. Then when you know better, do better."** This learning pathway is designed with that learning spirit in mind.
description: Learners have a better understanding of what it means to be “anti-racist” and what role they have within the BC Public Service in improving their capacities to respond to discrimination and racism at work.
name: Anti-Racism in the BC Public Service

bookmarks.description: A history of racism in British Columbia.
bookmarks.title: Challenging Racist British Columbia

bookmarks.description: Indigenous, Chinese, Japanese, Punjabi, Black, and European stories are woven together to present an astute look at the complicated histories that shaped BC as we know it today.
bookmarks.title: British Columbia: An Untold History | Knowledge.ca

bookmarks.description: Canada is usually referred to as a country of immigration, a country open to difference, a country that embraces multiculturalism. But more and more voices are rising to denounce ordinary or systemic racism and racist incidents, some of them tragic.
bookmarks.title: Racism in Canada: Words to tell wrongs | Radio-Canada.ca

steps.name: History of Racism in Canada
steps.objective: Learn about the history of racism in Canada to better understand the current context. "Contemporary racial oppression still has deeply connected roots in past racial oppression” and our societies operate within a racial frame that centers whiteness (Elias & Feagin, 2020, p. 21).
steps.pauseAndReflect:
* Having finished reading and watching the recommended articles and videos, how would you define anti-racism in your own words?
* To what degree are you aware of any anti-racism initiatives in your workplace?

bookmarks.description: Key Definitions for Anti-Racism in the BCPS
bookmarks.title: Key Definitions | Anti-Racism in the BCPS - Learning Curator Pathway Aid

bookmarks.description: In this extract from his 2019 book How To Be an Antiracist, historian Ibram X. Kendi breaks down exactly what the term means – and why clear language is a vital first step in the battle against prejudice.
bookmarks.title: Ibram X. Kendi defines what it means to be an antiracist

bookmarks.description: Introduction to Unlearning & Undoing White Supremacy and Racism in the Office of the Provincial Health Officer
bookmarks.title: Introduction to Unlearning & Undoing White Supremacy and Racism in the Office of the Provincial Health Officer - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.description: Anti-China sentiments — and political posturing — have led to racism against Asian Canadians.
bookmarks.title: White Supremacy in ‘British’ Columbia, and the China Syndrome | The Tyee

bookmarks.description: This website describes white supremacy culture as a framework for understanding racism. It allows us to explore the power structure and its imbalances in society.
bookmarks.title: What is White Supremacy Culture?

bookmarks.description: This New York times article introduces readers to the history of critical race theory in conceptualizing a framework needed in anti-racism studies.
bookmarks.title: What Is Critical Race Theory? A Brief History Explained - The New York Times

bookmarks.description: This CCDI-developed comprehensive glossary of terms provides a reference for terminology used within the Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI) and Accessibility learning space.
bookmarks.title: Canadian Centre for Diversity and Inclusion (CCDI) Glossary of Terms

bookmarks.description: In this interview, Professor Ibram X. Kendi discusses how being “anti-racist” differs from being “not racist.”
bookmarks.title: The difference between being "not racist" and antiracist | Ibram X. Kendi - YouTube

steps.name: Contextualize Racism and Anti-Racism
steps.objective: Understand the context in which racism exists. Learn about anti-racism and why simply being “not racist” isn't enough.
steps.pauseAndReflect:
* How would you identify yourself racially? Reflect on your identity and who you are in relation to the land and other community members both within the organization and society.
* As BC Public Service employees, what role do you believe we have in creating a racially just and safe organization and society where everyone can thrive?

bookmarks.description: To the uninitiated, Canada may have a reputation for friendly and folksy charm. For Black and Indigenous peoples of the 'Great White North,' this veneer beli...
bookmarks.title: Yes—Canada has anti-Black racism, too - YouTube

bookmarks.description:
From hate to hope
Inquiry into hate in the COVID-19 pandemic
In August 2021, B.C.’s Human Rights Commissioner launched an inquiry into the rise of hate in B.C. during the COVID-19 pandemic. In March 2023, the Commissioner released her findings and recommendations.

Illustrations by Paige Jung
bookmarks.title: From hate to hope | BC's Office of the Human Rights Commissioner

bookmarks.description: Rampant Islamophobia is costing Canadian Muslims their peace of mind, their physical well-being and even their lives.
bookmarks.title: Combatting Hate: Islamophobia and its impact on Muslims in Canada

bookmarks.description: Participate in the investigation into Indigenous-specific discrimination in the health system in BC.
bookmarks.title: Addressing Racism in BC Health Care

bookmarks.description: This Montreal Holocaust Museum report uncovers the history of Antisemitism that greatly affects the Jewish community in Canada.
bookmarks.title: Brief History of Antisemitism in Canada

bookmarks.description: This 2019 survey of Canadian public opinion and experience by the Canadian Race Relations Foundation found that racialized people experienced racism both in the workplace and out on the streets more than in any other setting.
bookmarks.title: Race Relations in Canada 2019: A survey of Canadian public opinion and experience

bookmarks.description: This article discusses racial trauma among the Black, Indigenous, and Other People of Colour (BIPOC) population in Canada.
bookmarks.title: The Traumatizing Impact of Racism in Canadians of Colour - PMC

steps.name: Colours of Racism in Canada
steps.objective: Understand the different types of racism and discrimination that Indigenous, Black, and other racialized and marginalized people experience in the Canadian context.
steps.pauseAndReflect: * As you reflect on various forms of systemic and structural racism, what more can we do to promote equity, diversity and inclusion in our workplace and society?

bookmarks.description: The Action Plan outlines goals and outcomes for ending Indigenous-specific racism and discrimination in British Columbia.
bookmarks.title: Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act Action Plan

bookmarks.description: The Human Rights Code helps protect people against discrimination in B.C. based on parts of their identity.
bookmarks.title: Human rights in B.C. | BC's Office of the Human Rights Commissioner

bookmarks.description: On May 2, 2022, we introduced the Anti-Racism Data Act. Its one of the first pieces of legislation to be co-developed with Indigenous Peoples under the Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples Act.
bookmarks.title: The Anti-Racism Data Act -

bookmarks.description: The purpose of this policy is to promote safe, healthy BC Public Service workplaces, free from discrimination, bullying and harassment. This policy covers individual behaviours and accountability. The BC Public Service, in cooperation with its unions and associations, is committed to promoting respectful behaviour. Respectful behaviour reflects BC Public Service corporate ethics and values, supports diversity and inclusion and promotes positive communication and collaborative working relationships – all essential to fostering public trust and confidence in the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: HR Policy 11 – Discrimination, Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace

bookmarks.description: This policy statement applies to all persons and organizations covered by the Public Service Act. The policy statement supports the core policy objective that “public service employees exhibit the highest standards of conduct.”
bookmarks.title: HR Policy 09 – Standards of Conduct for BC Public Service Employees

bookmarks.description: The BC Public Service is an inclusive employer representative of the people of British Columbia. Everyone belongs. This page outlines Where We All Belong, the three-year diversity and inclusion strategy for the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: Equity, Diversity & Inclusion Strategy for the BC Public Service - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.description: The corporate HR plan sets the strategic vision and guiding direction for the BC Public Service.
bookmarks.title: 2023 Corporate HR Plan

bookmarks.description: How to address a workplace conflict
bookmarks.title: Address a respectful workplace issue - Province of British Columbia

bookmarks.description: This Report examines the development of anti-racism legislation in three Canadian provinces and underscores the existing Pan-Canadian gaps.
bookmarks.title: A Progress Report on Anti-Racism Policy Across Canada

bookmarks.description: Among others, section 15 of the Charter of Rights addresses our right to be free from discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age and mental or physical disability.
bookmarks.title: Charter of Rights and Freedoms

steps.name: Existing Legislation, Policies and Strategies
steps.objective: This module emphasizes on the relevant legislations and policies available in British Columbia.

bookmarks.title: BCGEU Anti-Racism Resources

bookmarks.context: A picture is worth 1000 words.
bookmarks.description: Becoming Anti-Racist Infographic describes the different zones an individual progresses through on their journey to being Anti-Racist.
bookmarks.title: Anti-Racist "Zones" Infographic

bookmarks.description: This opinion piece presents three critical elements for creating a roadmap that helps individuals learn how to be actively anti-racist.
bookmarks.title: What You Can Do to Create an Anti-Racist Organization

bookmarks.description: Resilience BCs Anti-Racism Network provides tools to help you make a future free of racism and hate a reality.
bookmarks.title: Resilience BC

bookmarks.description: The toolkit was created by BCs Office of the Human Rights Commissioner (BCOHRC) to help employers learn how to improve employment equity within their businesses and organizations.
bookmarks.title: Anti-discrimination policies and addressing complaints

bookmarks.title: Anti-Racism Awareness Course

steps.pauseAndReflect: Can you think of other policies, strategies, resources, and learnings that must be implemented to prevent racism and discrimination in the BC Public Service?

title: Anti-Racism in the BC Public Service

steps.name: Accessibility
steps.objective: A broad but essential topic that should be considered in the early planning stages of any project and not treated as an afterthought. It takes more that passing some automated tests to have a good accessibility story. These resources will show you how.
steps.pauseAndReflect:
- Can you add these practices to your work?
- Ponder your own accessibility issues. How do you take advantage of accommodations?

bookmarks.title: Introduction to Web Accessibility | Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) | W3C
bookmarks.description: Accessibility resources free online from the international standards organization: W3C Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI).

bookmarks.title: Accessibility on Mozilla Developer Network (MDN)
bookmarks.description:
Accessibility (often abbreviated to A11y — as in, "a", then 11 characters, and then "y") in web development means enabling as many people as possible to use websites, even when those people's abilities are limited in some way.

For many people, technology makes things easier. For people with disabilities, technology makes things possible. Accessibility means developing content to be as accessible as possible, no matter an individual's physical and cognitive abilities and how they access the web.

The Web is fundamentally designed to work for all people, whatever their hardware, software, language, location, or ability. When the Web meets this goal, it is accessible to people with a diverse range of hearing, movement, sight, and cognitive ability.
– (W3C - Accessibility)
bookmarks.context: A wonderful resource that will take you far.

bookmarks.title: A11Y Project
bookmarks.description: Learn the fundamentals and principles behind accessible design
bookmarks.context: Start here.

bookmarks.title: Semantics - MDN Web Docs Glossary: Definitions of Web-related terms | MDN
bookmarks.description: In programming, Semantics refers to the meaning of a piece of code — for example "what effect does running that line of JavaScript have?", or "what purpose or role does that HTML element have" (rather than "what does it look like?".)
bookmarks.context: Learn this stuff deeply. Knowing how to structure HTML well will serve you well.

bookmarks.description: This page offers a better way to create a strong, yet easy to remember, passphrase for use with encryption and security programs. Weak passwords and passphrases are one of the most common flaws in computer security. Take a few minutes and learn how to do it right. The information presented here can be used by anyone. No background in cryptography or mathematics is required. Just follow the simple steps below.

bookmarks.description: Mojibake (Japanese: 文字化け; IPA: [mod͡ʑibake], 'character transformation') is the garbled or gibberish text that is the result of text being decoded using an unintended character encoding.[1] The result is a systematic replacement of symbols with completely unrelated ones, often from a different writing system.
